research.title: IMPACT-Lab Overview
research.content: Our research focuses on Intelligent Modeling of Planetary Accretion, Convection, and Tectonics (IMPACT). We aim to uncover how initial conditions, mantle dynamics, and geochemical differentiation have shaped Earth and other planets. By leveraging cutting-edge AI/ML techniques together with interdisciplinary geophysical and geochemical models, we seek to answer fundamental questions about planetary formation, interior evolution, and long-term habitability.

sections.title: Geophysics
sections.content: We study Earth's deep structure using seismic data and numerical modeling to understand mantle dynamics and the origin of large-scale heterogeneities.

sections.title: Geochemistry
sections.content: Our geochemical research focuses on isotopic systems that preserve information about Earth's early history and ongoing processes.

sections.title: Igneous Petrology
sections.content: We investigate magmatic processes and the formation of igneous rocks to understand crustal evolution and mantle-crust interactions.

sections.title: Geochronology
sections.content: Using advanced dating techniques, we determine the timing of geological processes and construct temporal frameworks for Earth's evolution.

people.title: IMPACT Team
people.content: The IMPACT Group (Intelligent Modeling of Planetary Accretion, Convection, and Tectonics) in the Department of Geology & Geophysics at Texas A&M is part of the Research in Artificial Intelligence for Science and Engineering (RAISE) Initiative. We leverage AI/ML to build next-generation Earth and planetary simulations, tackling some of the biggest puzzles in Earth and other worlds. Our team values multidisciplinary collaboration, diversity, and a strong research spirit. If you‚Äôre interested in a PhD, postdoc, or undergraduate project, contact the PI at qyuan@tamu.edu

newsItems.title: New Research Published in Nature Geoscience
newsItems.excerpt: Our latest study on the giant impact origin of Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces has been published in Nature Geoscience, providing new insights into Earth's early bombardment history.
newsItems.content:
This groundbreaking research presents compelling evidence that the mysterious Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces (LLSVPs) in Earth's lower mantle may be remnants of ancient giant impact events. Using advanced numerical modeling and seismic analysis, our team has demonstrated how impact-generated material could have settled in the lower mantle and persisted for billions of years.

The study employed high-resolution 3D numerical simulations to model the aftermath of giant impacts during Earth's early formation period, approximately 4.5 billion years ago. These simulations revealed that impact-generated material, enriched in iron and other heavy elements, would naturally segregate and accumulate in specific regions of the lower mantle due to gravitational settling and thermal convection patterns.

Our research team collaborated with seismologists from multiple institutions to compare our computational predictions with observed seismic data from global monitoring networks. The correlation between our modeled structures and the actual locations and properties of LLSVPs provides strong support for the giant impact hypothesis.

This work has significant implications for understanding not only Earth's early evolution but also the formation processes of other terrestrial planets. The findings suggest that giant impacts played a more crucial role in shaping planetary interiors than previously recognized, potentially influencing magnetic field generation, volcanism patterns, and long-term geological evolution.
keyFindings: Numerical models demonstrate how giant impact events during Earth's formation could have created persistent heterogeneities in the lower mantle
Seismic tomography data shows structural similarities between observed LLSVPs and our impact-generated models
New insights into the thermal and chemical evolution of Earth's deep interior over geological timescales
Implications for understanding early Earth bombardment history and planetary formation processes

newsItems.title: Dr. Yuan Receives NSF CAREER Award
newsItems.excerpt: Principal Investigator Dr. Qian Yuan has been awarded the prestigious NSF CAREER Award for research on early Earth evolution and mantle dynamics.
newsItems.content:
The National Science Foundation CAREER Award recognizes early-career faculty who have the potential to serve as academic role models in research and education. This five-year, $500,000 award will support Dr. Yuan's research on understanding the formation and evolution of Earth's deep structure through the integration of geophysical modeling and geochemical analysis.

The CAREER Award proposal, titled 'Deciphering Earth's Early Evolution Through Integrated Geophysical and Geochemical Modeling,' outlines an ambitious research program that will combine cutting-edge computational techniques with laboratory experiments and field observations. The project aims to reconstruct the conditions and processes that shaped our planet during its first billion years of existence.

A significant component of the award includes educational outreach activities designed to engage undergraduate students, particularly those from underrepresented groups, in Earth science research. Dr. Yuan plans to develop new curriculum modules that incorporate real research data and computational tools, providing students with hands-on experience in modern geophysical research methods.

The research will also establish new collaborations with international institutions and provide training opportunities for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. The interdisciplinary nature of the project will foster connections between geophysics, geochemistry, and planetary science communities, advancing our understanding of terrestrial planet formation and evolution.
keyFindings: Recognition of Dr. Yuan's innovative approach to integrating computational geophysics with geochemical constraints
Funding secured for five years of cutting-edge research on early Earth evolution
Educational component will train next generation of Earth scientists in interdisciplinary research methods
International collaborations established to advance understanding of planetary formation processes

newsItems.title: New Collaboration with Stanford University
newsItems.excerpt: We are excited to announce a new research collaboration with Stanford University's Department of Geophysics to study subduction initiation processes.
newsItems.content:
This collaboration brings together expertise in computational geodynamics and seismic tomography to investigate the mechanisms that trigger the onset of subduction. The partnership will involve joint field work, shared computational resources, and student exchange programs.

The three-year collaborative project, funded by a joint NSF grant, focuses on understanding the complex processes that lead to the formation of new subduction zones. By combining our group's expertise in numerical modeling with Stanford's advanced seismic imaging capabilities, we aim to develop a comprehensive framework for predicting where and when new subduction zones might form.

The collaboration includes access to Stanford's high-performance computing facilities and their extensive seismic database covering the Pacific Ring of Fire. Our team will contribute advanced thermochemical modeling techniques and expertise in mantle dynamics to create more realistic simulations of subduction initiation scenarios.

Student exchange programs will allow graduate students from both institutions to gain experience with different research methodologies and analytical techniques. This cross-training approach will prepare the next generation of geophysicists to tackle complex, interdisciplinary problems in Earth science.
keyFindings: Joint research initiative combining computational geodynamics with seismic tomography expertise
Access to Stanford's high-performance computing facilities and Pacific Ring of Fire seismic database
Student exchange programs fostering interdisciplinary training in modern geophysical methods
Development of new predictive frameworks for subduction zone formation and evolution

newsItems.title: Graduate Student Wins Best Poster Award
newsItems.excerpt: PhD student Michael Chen received the Best Poster Award at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting for his work on mantle convection modeling.
newsItems.content:
Michael's poster presentation on 'High-Resolution Modeling of Mantle Convection with Compositional Heterogeneities' impressed judges with its innovative approach to understanding how chemical variations in the mantle affect convection patterns. This research has important implications for understanding the long-term evolution of Earth's interior.

The award-winning research employed state-of-the-art computational techniques to model mantle convection at unprecedented resolution, incorporating realistic compositional variations based on geochemical observations. Michael's work revealed how small-scale chemical heterogeneities can significantly influence large-scale convection patterns and heat transfer in the mantle.

The study utilized over 2 million CPU hours on national supercomputing facilities to run high-resolution 3D simulations spanning billions of years of Earth's evolution. The results provide new insights into how the mantle's chemical structure has evolved over geological time and how it continues to influence surface processes today.

Michael's presentation stood out among over 500 poster presentations in the geodynamics section, earning recognition for both its scientific rigor and clear communication of complex concepts. The research has already attracted interest from several international research groups and is being prepared for publication in a high-impact journal.
keyFindings: High-resolution 3D simulations reveal how compositional heterogeneities influence mantle convection patterns
New computational techniques enable modeling of mantle evolution over billion-year timescales
Small-scale chemical variations shown to have significant impact on large-scale heat transfer processes
Research provides new framework for understanding mantle-surface interactions throughout Earth's history

newsItems.title: Featured in National Geographic Documentary
newsItems.excerpt: Our research on Earth's early evolution will be featured in an upcoming National Geographic documentary about the formation of our planet.
newsItems.content:
The documentary, titled 'Birth of a Planet,' will showcase our work on giant impacts and their role in shaping Earth's structure. Filming included interviews with team members and visualization of our computational models. The documentary is scheduled to air in spring 2024.

The production team spent three days in our laboratory, capturing both the scientific process and the human stories behind our research. Dr. Yuan and several graduate students were interviewed about their work on modeling the early Earth's bombardment period and its lasting effects on planetary structure.

A highlight of the documentary features cutting-edge visualizations of our computational models, showing how giant impacts during Earth's formation created the deep structural anomalies we observe today. The production team worked closely with our visualization specialists to create scientifically accurate animations that bring billions of years of Earth's evolution to life.

The documentary aims to make complex geophysical concepts accessible to general audiences while maintaining scientific accuracy. It represents an important opportunity to share our research findings with millions of viewers worldwide and inspire the next generation of Earth scientists.
keyFindings: National Geographic platform provides unprecedented reach for sharing Earth science research with global audiences
Advanced scientific visualizations make complex geophysical processes accessible to general public
Documentary showcases real-world applications of computational modeling in understanding planetary formation
Collaboration demonstrates importance of science communication in advancing public understanding of Earth sciences

newsItems.title: New Equipment Enhances Laboratory Capabilities
newsItems.excerpt: Installation of a new high-precision mass spectrometer significantly expands our analytical capabilities for isotopic studies.
newsItems.content:
The new Thermo Fisher Scientific Neptune Plus MC-ICP-MS enables us to perform ultra-high precision isotopic measurements on small sample sizes. This capability is crucial for our research on early Earth materials and will support multiple ongoing projects in geochemistry and geochronology.

The installation process required extensive laboratory renovations, including specialized vibration isolation systems and clean room protocols to ensure optimal instrument performance. The instrument features 16 Faraday collectors and multiple ion counters, allowing simultaneous measurement of multiple isotopes with unprecedented precision.

This new analytical capability opens up exciting research opportunities, particularly in studying ancient zircon crystals and meteorite samples that provide insights into early Earth conditions. The instrument's ability to analyze samples as small as a few nanograms makes it possible to study individual mineral grains and extract detailed isotopic information from precious samples.

The acquisition was made possible through a combination of NSF funding, university support, and industry partnerships. Training programs for graduate students and postdocs are already underway, ensuring that the next generation of researchers will be proficient in these advanced analytical techniques.
keyFindings: Ultra-high precision isotopic measurements now possible on nanogram-scale samples
Enhanced capabilities for studying ancient zircon crystals and meteorite samples
Simultaneous multi-isotope analysis significantly improves research efficiency and data quality
New training programs established to develop expertise in advanced analytical geochemistry
